citations.narrative:
Food is not being stored in an appropriate manner. In the outdoor building housing the dog food, a stack of 10 bags of
food was placed directly on the floor. Another stack of 10 bags of dog food was placed directly against the wall. On the
surfaces adjacent to the bags of dog food there was evidence of rodent droppings. Food bags placed directly on the floor
or against walls could become contaminated by pests such as rodents leading to possible illness to the animals. Correct
by ensuring supplies of food and bedding are stored in a manner that protects the supplies from spoilage, contamination,
and vermin infestation. The supplies must be stored off the floor and away from the walls, to allow cleaning underneath
and around the supplies. All food must be stored in a manner that prevents contamination and deterioration of its nutritive
value.

Enclosures are not protecting animals from injury:
-Exposed electrical cords are accessible to the animals in three enclosures each housing approximately 1 adult dog. Most
of the enclosures housing animals also contain exposed electrical outlets accessible to the animals.
-Fly strips are accessible to the animals in four enclosures each housing approximately 1 adult dog.
-Several exposed nails accessible to the animals are seen on the ceiling of two outside runs each housing approximately
one adult dog.
Sharp points, electrical cords, and fly strips that are accessible to the animals could cause injury and distress to the
animals. Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that they protect the dogs from injury. Correct by
ensuring that the enclosures protect the animals from injury.

The facility is not following the sampling schedule in the written Program of Veterinary Care (PVC). The PVC states to
perform fecal sampling of 10 percent of adult dogs each year. The facility does not perform fecal testing on adult dogs.
Failure to perform fecal sampling in accordance with a veterinary approved schedule may result in animals to not be
adequately protected against disease and can cause pain and distress. Correct by ensuring that animals are tested in
accordance with the schedule approved by the Attending Veterinarian.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by March 15, 2026 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
3.1(e) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
Food is not being stored in an appropriate manner. In the outdoor building housing the dog food, a stack of 10 bags of 
food was placed directly on the floor. Another stack of 10 bags of dog food was placed directly against the wall. On the 
surfaces adjacent to the bags of dog food there was evidence of rodent droppings. Food bags placed directly on the floor 
or against walls could become contaminated by pests such as rodents leading to possible illness to the animals. Correct 
by ensuring supplies of food and bedding are stored in a manner that protects the supplies from spoilage, contamination, 
and vermin infestation. The supplies must be stored off the floor and away from the walls, to allow cleaning underneath 
and around the supplies. All food must be stored in a manner that prevents contamination and deterioration of its nutritive 
value. 
3.6(a)(2)(ii) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
Enclosures are not protecting animals from injury: 
 
-Exposed electrical cords are accessible to the animals in three enclosures each housing approximately 1 adult dog. Most 
of the enclosures housing animals also contain exposed electrical outlets accessible to the animals. 
-Fly strips are accessible to the animals in four enclosures each housing approximately 1 adult dog. 
-Several exposed nails accessible to the animals are seen on the ceiling of two outside runs each housing approximately 
one adult dog. 
 
Sharp points, electrical cords, and fly strips that are accessible to the animals could cause injury and distress to the 
animals. Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that they protect the dogs from injury. Correct by 
ensuring that the enclosures protect the animals from injury. 
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The facility is not following the sampling schedule in the written Program of Veterinary Care (PVC). The PVC states to 
perform fecal sampling of 10 percent of adult dogs each year. The facility does not perform fecal testing on adult dogs.

Failure to perform fecal sampling in accordance with a veterinary approved schedule may result in animals to not be 
adequately protected against disease and can cause pain and distress. Correct by ensuring that animals are tested in 
accordance with the schedule approved by the Attending Veterinarian. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by March 15, 2026 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee 
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
 n
